2133    /**
2134     *  Replaces the variables of the form <code>${&lt;<i>name</i>&gt;}</code>
2135     *  in the given String with values from the given maps. The method will
2136     *  try the maps in the given sequence.<br>
2137     *  <br>If no replacement value could be found, the variable will not be
2138     *  replaced at all.<br>
2139     *  <br>If a value from one of the maps contains a variable itself, this
2140     *  will not be replaced.<br>
2141     *  <br>The variables names are case-sensitive.<br>
2142     *  <br>Valid variable name may not contain other characters than the
2143     *  letters from 'a' to 'z' (upper case and lower case), the digits from
2144     *  '0' to '9' and the special characters underscore ('_') and dot ('.'),
2145     *  after an optional prefix character.<br>
2146     *  <br>Allowed prefixes are the tilde ('~'), the slash ('/'), the equal
2147     *  sign ('='), the colon (':'), the percent sign ('%'), and the ampersand
2148     *  ('&amp;').<br>
2149     *  <br>The prefix character is part of the name.<br>
2150     *  <br>Finally, there is the single underscore that is allowed as a
2151     *  special variable.
2152     *
2153     *  @param  text    The text with the variables; may be {@code null}.
2154     *  @param  sources The maps with the replacement values.
2155     *  @return The new text, or {@code null} if the provided value for
2156     *      {@code text} was already {@code null}.
2157     *
2158     *  @see #VARIABLE_PATTERN
2159     *
2160     *  @since 0.0.5
2161     *  @deprecated Use
2162     *      {@link Template#replaceVariable(CharSequence, Map[])}
2163     *      instead.
2164     */
2165    @SafeVarargs
2166    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2167    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2168    public static final String replaceVariable( final CharSequence text, final Map<String,? extends Object>... sources )
2169    {
2170        return Template.replaceVariable( text, sources );
2171    }   //  replaceVariable()
2172
2173    /**
2174     *  Replaces the variables of the form <code>${&lt;<i>name</i>&gt;}</code>
2175     *  in the given String with values returned by the given retriever
2176     *  function for the variable name.<br>
2177     *  <br>If no replacement value could be found, the variable will not be
2178     *  replaced at all.<br>
2179     *  <br>If the retriever function returns a value that contains a variable
2180     *  itself, this will not be replaced.<br>
2181     *  <br>The retriever function will be called only once for each variable
2182     *  name; if the text contains the same variable multiple times, it will
2183     *  always be replaced with the same value.<br>
2184     *  <br>The variables names are case-sensitive.<br>
2185     *  <br>Valid variable name may not contain other characters than the
2186     *  letters from 'a' to 'z' (upper case and lower case), the digits from
2187     *  '0' to '9' and the special characters underscore ('_') and dot ('.'),
2188     *  after an optional prefix character.<br>
2189     *  <br>Allowed prefixes are the tilde ('~'), the slash ('/'), the equal
2190     *  sign ('='), the colon (':'), the percent sign ('%'), and the ampersand
2191     *  ('&amp;').<br>
2192     *  <br>The prefix character is part of the name.<br>
2193     *  <br>Finally, there is the single underscore that is allowed as a
2194     *  special variable.
2195     *
2196     *  @param  text    The text with the variables; may be {@code null}.
2197     *  @param  retriever   The function that will retrieve the replacement
2198     *      values for the given variable names.
2199     *  @return The new text, or {@code null} if the provided value for
2200     *      {@code text} was already {@code null}.
2201     *
2202     *  @see #VARIABLE_PATTERN
2203     *
2204     *  @since 0.0.5
2205     *  @deprecated Use
2206     *      {@link Template#replaceVariable(CharSequence, Function)}
2207     *      instead.
2208     */
2209    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2210    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2211    public static final String replaceVariable( final CharSequence text, final Function<? super String, Optional<String>> retriever )
2212    {
2213        return Template.replaceVariable( text, retriever );
2214    }   //  replaceVariable()
2215
2216    /**
2217     *  Splits a String by the given separator character and returns an array
2218     *  of all parts. In case a separator character is immediately followed by
2219     *  another separator char, an empty String will be place to the array.
2220     *  Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
2221     *  first character of the String is a separator, the returned array will
2222     *  start with an empty string, as it will end with an empty String if the
2223     *  last character is a separator.<br>
2224     *  <br>In case the String is empty, the return value will be an array
2225     *  containing just the empty String.
2226     *
2227     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2228     *  @param  separator   The separator character.
2229     *  @return The parts of the String.
2230     *
2231     *  @since 0.0.5
2232     */
2233    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2234    public static final String [] splitString( final CharSequence string, final char separator )
2235    {
2236        return splitString( string, (int) separator );
2237    }   //  splitString()
2238
2239    /**
2240     *  Splits a String by the given separator character, identified by its
2241     *  Unicode code point, and returns an array of all parts. In case a
2242     *  separator character is immediately followed by another separator char,
2243     *  an empty String will be placed to the array. Beginning and end of the
2244     *  String are treated as separators, so if the first character of the
2245     *  String is a separator, the returned array will start with an empty
2246     *  String, as it will end with an empty String if the last character is a
2247     *  separator.<br>
2248     *  <br>In case the String is empty, the return value will be an array
2249     *  containing just the empty String.
2250     *
2251     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2252     *  @param  separator   The code point for the separator character.
2253     *  @return The parts of the String.
2254     *
2255     *  @since 0.0.5
2256     */
2257    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2258    public static final String [] splitString( final CharSequence string, final int separator )
2259    {
2260        final var retValue = stream( string, separator ).toArray( String []::new );
2261
2262        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2263        return retValue;
2264    }   //  splitString()
2265
2266    /**
2267     *  Splits a String by the given separator sequence and returns an array
2268     *  of all parts. In case a separator sequence is immediately followed by
2269     *  another separator sequence, an empty String will be placed to the
2270     *  array. Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if
2271     *  the first part of the String equals the separator sequence, the
2272     *  returned array will start with an empty String, as it will end with an
2273     *  empty string if the last part would equal the separator sequence..<br>
2274     *  <br>In case the String is empty, the return value will be an array
2275     *  containing just the empty String.
2276     *
2277     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2278     *  @param  separator   The separator sequence.
2279     *  @return The parts of the String.
2280     *
2281     *  @since 0.0.5
2282     */
2283    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2284    public static final String [] splitString( final CharSequence string, final CharSequence separator )
2285    {
2286        final var retValue = stream( string, separator).toArray( String []::new );
2287
2288        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2289        return retValue;
2290    }   //  splitString()
2291
2292    /**
2293     *  Splits a String by the given separator character and returns a
2294     *  {@link Stream}
2295     *  of all parts. In case a separator character is immediately followed by
2296     *  another separator char, an empty String will be put to the
2297     *  {@code Stream}. Beginning and end of the String are treated as
2298     *  separators, so if the first character of the String is a separator, the
2299     *  returned {@code Stream} will start with an empty String, as it will end
2300     *  with an empty String if the last character is a separator.<br>
2301     *  <br>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2302     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String.
2303     *
2304     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2305     *  @param  separator   The separator character.
2306     *  @return A {@code Stream} instance with the parts of the String.
2307     *
2308     *  @since 0.0.7
2309     */
2310    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2311    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence string, final char separator )
2312    {
2313        return stream( string, (int) separator );
2314    }   //  stream()
2315
2316    /**
2317     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String by the given separator character, identified by its
2318     *  Unicode code point, and returns a
2319     *  {@link Stream}
2320     *  of all parts.} In case a separator character is immediately followed by
2321     *  another separator char, an empty String will be put to the
2322     *  {@code Stream}. Beginning and end of the String are treated as
2323     *  separators, so if the first character of the String is a separator, the
2324     *  returned {@code Stream} will start with an empty String, as it will end
2325     *  with an empty String if the last character is a separator.</p>
2326     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2327     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String.</p>
2328     *
2329     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2330     *  @param  separator   The code point for the separator character.
2331     *  @return A {@code Stream} instance with the parts of the String.
2332     *
2333     *  @since 0.0.7
2334     */
2335    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2336    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence string, final int separator )
2337    {
2338        //---* Process the string *--------------------------------------------
2339        final var s = requireNonNullArgument( string, "string" ).codePoints().toArray();
2340        final var builder = Stream.<String>builder();
2341        var begin = -1;
2342        for( var i = 0 ; i < s.length; ++i )
2343        {
2344            if( begin == -1 )
2345            {
2346                begin = i;
2347            }
2348            if( s [ i ] == separator )
2349            {
2350                builder.add( new String( s, begin, i - begin ).intern() );
2351                begin = -1;
2352            }
2353        }
2354
2355        //---* Add the rest *--------------------------------------------------
2356        if( (begin >= 0) && (begin < s.length) )
2357        {
2358            builder.add( new String( s, begin, s.length - begin ).intern() );
2359        }
2360        if( (s.length == 0) || (s [s.length - 1] == separator) )
2361        {
2362            builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2363        }
2364
2365        //---* Create the return value *---------------------------------------
2366        final var retValue = builder.build();
2367
2368        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2369        return retValue;
2370    }   //  stream()
2371
2372    /**
2373     *  Splits a String by the given separator sequence and returns a
2374     *  {@link Stream}
2375     *  of all parts. In case a separator sequence is immediately followed by
2376     *  another separator sequence, an empty String will be put to the
2377     *  {@code Stream}. Beginning and end of the String are treated as
2378     *  separators, so if the first part of the String equals the separator
2379     *  sequence, the returned {@code Stream} will start with an empty string,
2380     *  as it will end with an empty String if the last part would equal the
2381     *  separator sequence.<br>
2382     *  <br>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2383     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String.
2384     *
2385     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2386     *  @param  separator   The separator sequence.
2387     *  @return The parts of the String.
2388     *
2389     *  @since 0.0.7
2390     */
2391    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2392    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence string, final CharSequence separator )
2393    {
2394        //---* Process the string *--------------------------------------------
2395        var s = requireNonNullArgument( string, "string" ).toString();
2396        final var t = requireNotEmptyArgument( separator, "separator" ).toString();
2397
2398        final var builder = Stream.<String>builder();
2399        var pos = Integer.MAX_VALUE;
2400        while( isNotEmpty( s ) && (pos >= 0) )
2401        {
2402            pos = s.indexOf( t );
2403            switch( Integer.signum( pos ) )
2404            {
2405                case 0 -> /* String starts with separator */
2406                    {
2407                        builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2408                        s = s.substring( t.length() );
2409                    }
2410                case 1 -> /* String contains a separator somewhere */
2411                    {
2412                        builder.add( s.substring( 0, pos ) );
2413                        s = s.substring( pos + t.length() );
2414                    }
2415                case -1 -> { /* Just leave the loop */ }
2416            }   //  ResultHandlerSwitch:
2417        }
2418
2419        //---* Add the rest *--------------------------------------------------
2420        builder.add( s );
2421
2422        //---* Create the return value *---------------------------------------
2423        final var retValue = builder.build();
2424
2425        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2426        return retValue;
2427    }   //  stream()
2428
2429    /**
2430     *  Splits a String using the given regular expression and returns a
2431     *  {@link Stream}
2432     *  of all parts. In case a separator sequence is immediately followed by
2433     *  another separator sequence, an empty String will be put to the
2434     *  {@code Stream}. Beginning and end of the String are treated as
2435     *  separators, so if the first part of the String equals the separator
2436     *  sequence, the returned {@code Stream} will start with an empty string,
2437     *  as it will end with an empty String if the last part would equal the
2438     *  separator sequence.<br>
2439     *  <br>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2440     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String.
2441     *
2442     *  @note This method behaves different from
2443     *      {@link String#split(String)}
2444     *      as it will return trailing empty Strings.
2445     *
2446     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2447     *  @param  pattern The separator sequence.
2448     *  @return The parts of the String.
2449     *
2450     *  @see String#split(String)
2451     *  @see Pattern#split(CharSequence)
2452     *
2453     *  @since 0.0.7
2454     */
2455    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2456    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence string, final Pattern pattern )
2457    {
2458        requireNonNullArgument( pattern, "pattern" );
2459
2460        //---* Process the string *--------------------------------------------
2461        final var builder = Stream.<String>builder();
2462        if( isEmpty( requireNonNullArgument( string, "string" ) ) )
2463        {
2464            builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2465        }
2466        else
2467        {
2468            final var parts = pattern.split( string );
2469            for( final var part : parts )
2470            {
2471                builder.add( part );
2472            }
2473            final var matcher = pattern.matcher( string );
2474            var count = 0;
2475            while( matcher.find() ) ++count;
2476            //noinspection ForLoopWithMissingComponent
2477            for( ; count >= parts.length; --count )
2478            {
2479                builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2480            }
2481        }
2482
2483        //---* Create the return value *---------------------------------------
2484        final var retValue = builder.build();
2485
2486        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2487        return retValue;
2488    }   //  stream()
2489
2490    /**
2491     *  Strips HTML or XML tags from the given String, without touching other
2492     *  entities (like {@code &amp;} or {@code &nbsp;}). The result would be
2493     *  the effective text, stripped from all other whitespace (except single
2494     *  blanks).<br>
2495     *  <br>This means that the result for
2496     *  <pre><code>stripTags( &quot;&lt;html&gt;
2497     *      &lt;head&gt;
2498     *        &hellip;
2499     *      &lt;/head&gt;
2500     *      &lt;body&gt;
2501     *        &lt;a href='&hellip;'&gt;       Simple          &lt;br&gt;
2502     *          &lt;br&gt;           Text       &lt;/a&gt;
2503     *      &lt;/body&gt;
2504     *  &lt;/html&gt;&quot; )</code></pre> would be just
2505     *  &quot;{@code Simple Text}&quot;.<br>
2506     *  <br>Comments will be stripped as well, and {@code <pre>} tags are not
2507     *  interpreted, with the consequence that any formatting with whitespace
2508     *  gets lost. {@code CDATA} elements are stripped, too.
2509     *
2510     *  @param  s   The HTML/XML string.
2511     *  @return The string without the tags.
2512     *
2513     *  @since 0.0.7
2514     */
2515    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2516    public static final String stripTags( final CharSequence s )
2517    {
2518        final var retValue = new StringBuilder();
2519        if( isNotEmptyOrBlank( requireNonNullArgument( s, "s" ) ) )
2520        {
2521            final var matcher = m_TagRemovalPattern.matcher( s );
2522            final var buffer = matcher.replaceAll( " " ).trim().codePoints().toArray();
2523            int lastChar = NULL_CHAR;
2524            ScanLoop: for( final var c : buffer )
2525            {
2526                if( isWhitespace( c ) )
2527                {
2528                    //---* Consecutive whitespace detected *-------------------
2529                    if( isWhitespace( lastChar ) ) continue ScanLoop;
2530
2531                    //---* All resulting whitespace have to be blanks *--------
2532                    retValue.append( " " );
2533                }
2534                else
2535                {
2536                    //---* Write the character *-------------------------------
2537                    retValue.append( toChars( c ) );
2538                }
2539                lastChar = c;
2540            }   //  ScanLoop:
2541        }
2542
2543        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2544        return retValue.toString();
2545    }   //  stripTags()
2546
2547    /**
2548     *  Strips characters from the given input that are not allowed (or should
2549     *  be at least avoided) for a file or folder name on most or all operating
2550     *  systems.<br>
2551     *  <br>The following characters will be stripped:
2552     *  <dl>
2553     *  <dt><b>:</b> (colon)</dt><dd>On Windows systems it is used to separate
2554     *  the drive letter from the path and file name; on Unix-like operating
2555     *  systems it would be valid, but it can cause issues on the {@code PATH}
2556     *  and {@code CLASSPATH} variables on that operating systems.</dd>
2557     *  <dt><b>\</b> (backslash)</dt><dd>On Windows systems it is used as the
2558     *  path separator, while on Unix-like operating systems it is problematic
2559     *  in other ways. For example, it is used to escape blanks in not-quoted
2560     *  file or folder names.</dd>
2561     *  <dt><b>/</b> (slash or forward slash)</dt><dd>The path separator on
2562     *  Unix-like operating systems, but Java will use it that way on Windows
2563     *  systems, too.</dd>
2564     *  <dt><b>;</b> (semicolon)</dt><dd>It can cause issues on the {@code PATH}
2565     *  and {@code CLASSPATH} variables on Windows.</dd>
2566     *  <dt><b>*</b> (asterisk)</dt><dd>The asterisk is often used as wild card
2567     *  character in shell programs to find groups of files; using it in a file
2568     *  name can cause funny effects.</dd>
2569     *  <dt><b>?</b> (question mark)</dt><dd>The question mark is used on
2570     *  Windows as a wild card for a single character; similar to the asterisk,
2571     *  it can cause funny effects when used in a file name.</dd>
2572     *  <dt><b>&quot;</b> (double quotes)</dt>
2573     *  <dt><b>'</b> (single quotes)</dt><dd>Both have some potential to
2574     *  confuse the various shell programs of all operating systems.</dd>
2575     *  <dt><b>@</b> ('at'-sign)</dt><dd>Although it is allowed for file and
2576     *  folder names, it causes issues when used in the URL for that respective
2577     *  file.</dd>
2578     *  <dt><b>|</b> (pipe symbol)</dt><dd>Similar to the '*' (asterisk), the
2579     *  pipe-symbol has â as the name already indicates - a meaning on most
2580     *  shells that would make it difficult to manage files that contains this
2581     *  character in their names.</dd>
2582     *  <dt><b>&lt;</b> (less than)</dt>
2583     *  <dt><b>&gt;</b> (greater than)</dt><dd>Like the pipe, these two have a
2584     *  meaning on most shells that would make it difficult to manage files
2585     *  that contains one of these characters in their names.</dd>
2586     *  <dt>Whitespace</dt><dd>Only blanks will remain, any other whitespace
2587     *  characters are stripped.</dd>
2588     *  </dl>
2589     *  Finally, the method will strip all leading and trailing blanks;
2590     *  although blanks are usually allowed, they are confusing when not
2591     *  surrounded by some visible characters.
2592     *  Especially regarding the characters that are critical for shells ('*',
2593     *  '?', '&quot;', ''', '|', '&lt;', and '&gt;') this method is
2594     *  over-cautious, as most shells could handle them after proper escaping
2595     *  the offending characters or quoting the file name.<br>
2596     *  <br>This method furthermore assumes that any other Unicode character is
2597     *  valid for a file or folder name; unfortunately, there are filesystems
2598     *  where this is not true.
2599     *
2600     *  @note   This method will not take care about the length of the returned
2601     *      String; this means the result to a call to this method may still be
2602     *      invalid as a file or folder name because it is too long.
2603     *
2604     *  @param  s   The input String, denoting a file or folder name -
2605     *      <i>not</i> a full path.
2606     *  @return The String without the characters that are invalid for a file
2607     *      name. This value will never be {@code null} or empty.
2608     *  @throws NullArgumentException   The input is {@code null}.
2609     *  @throws EmptyArgumentException  The input is the empty String.
2610     *  @throws ValidationException After stripping the invalid characters the
2611     *      return value would be empty.
2612     *
2613     *  @since 0.0.5
2614     */
2615    @SuppressWarnings( "SwitchStatementWithTooManyBranches" )
2616    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2617    public static final String stripToFilename( final CharSequence s ) throws ValidationException
2618    {
2619        final var len = requireNotEmptyArgument( s, "s" ).length();
2620        final var buffer = new StringBuilder( len );
2621        char c;
2622        ScanLoop: for( var i = 0; i < len; ++i )
2623        {
2624            c = s.charAt( i );
2625            Selector: switch( c )
2626            {
2627                case ':':
2628                case '\\':
2629                case '/':
2630                case ';':
2631                case '*':
2632                case '"':
2633                case '\'':
2634                case '@':
2635                case '|':
2636                case '?':
2637                case '<':
2638                case '>':
2639                    continue ScanLoop;
2640
2641                default:
2642                {
2643                    if( (c == ' ') || (!isISOControl( c ) && !isWhitespace( c )) )
2644                    {
2645                        buffer.append( c );
2646                    }
2647                    break Selector;
2648                }
2649            }   //  Selector:
2650        }   //  ScanLoop:
2651
2652        final var retValue = buffer.toString().trim();
2653        if( retValue.length() < 1 )
2654        {
2655            throw new ValidationException( format( "After stripping the invalid characters from '%1$s' there do not remain enough characters for a valid file name", s.toString() ) );
2656        }
2657
2658        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2659        return retValue;
2660    }   //  stripToFilename()
2661
2662    /**
2663     *  Strips HTML or XML comments from the given String.
2664     *
2665     *  @param  s   The HTML/XML string.
2666     *  @return The string without the comments.
2667     *
2668     *  @since 0.0.5
2669     */
2670    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2671    public static final String stripXMLComments( final CharSequence s )
2672    {
2673        final var matcher = m_CommentRemovalPattern.matcher( requireNonNullArgument( s, "s" ) );
2674        final var retValue = matcher.replaceAll( EMPTY_STRING );
2675
2676        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2677        return retValue;
2678    }   //  stripXMLComments()
2679
2680    /**
2681     *  Translates the given String to a String that will only contain
2682     *  printable ASCII characters; all other characters will be 'escaped' to
2683     *  the format &quot;&#92;uXXXX&quot;.
2684     *
2685     *  @param  s   The input string; may be {@code null}.
2686     *  @return The output string; {@code null} if the input string was
2687     *      already {@code null}.
2688     *
2689     *  @since 0.0.5
2690     *  @deprecated Use instead
2691     *      {@link CharSetUtils#convertUnicodeToASCII(java.text.Normalizer.Form, CharSequence)}
2692     *      with
2693     *      {@link java.text.Normalizer.Form#NFKC}
2694     *      as the first argument.
2695     */
2696    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2697    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2698    public static final String toUnicode( final CharSequence s )

2703    /**
2704     *  Changes the first letter of the given String tolower case as per
2705     *  {@link Character#toLowerCase(char)}.
2706     *  No other letters are changed. A {@code null} input String returns
2707     *  {@code null}.<br>
2708     *  <br>Samples:<pre><code>  StringUtils.uncapitalize( null ) = null;
2709     *  StringUtils.uncapitalize(&quot;&quot;)     = &quot;&quot;;
2710     *  StringUtils.uncapitalize(&quot;Cat&quot;)  = &quot;cat&quot;;
2711     *  StringUtils.uncapitalize(&quot;CAT&quot;)  = &quot;cAT&quot;;</code></pre>
2712     *  <br>Basically, this is the complementary method to
2713     *  {@link #capitalize(CharSequence)}.
2714     *  Use this method to normalise the name of bean attributes.
2715     *
2716     *  @param  s   The String to <i>uncapitalise</i>, may be {@code null}.
2717     *  @return The <i>uncapitalised</i> String, {@code null} if the argument
2718     *      was {@code null}.
2719     *  @see #capitalize(CharSequence)
2720     *
2721     *  @since 0.0.5
2722     *  @deprecated Use
2723     *      {@link #decapitalize(CharSequence)}
2724     *      instead.
2725     */
2726    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0" )
2727    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2728    public static final String uncapitalize( final CharSequence s ) { return decapitalize( s ); }

2730    /**
2731     *  Unescapes a string containing entity escapes to a string containing the
2732     *  actual Unicode characters corresponding to the escapes. Supports HTML
2733     *  5.0 entities.<br>
2734     *  <br>For example, the string
2735     *  &quot;&amp;lt;Fran&amp;ccedil;ais&amp;gt;&quot; will become
2736     *  &quot;&lt;Fran&ccedil;ais&gt;&quot;.<br>
2737     *  <br>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2738     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2739     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.
2740     *
2741     *  @param  str The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2742     *  @return A new unescaped {@code String}, {@code null} if the given
2743     *      string was already {@code null}.
2744     *
2745     *  @see #escapeHTML(CharSequence)
2746     *  @see #escapeHTML(Appendable,CharSequence)
2747     *
2748     *  @since 0.0.5
2749     */
2750    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2751    public static final String unescapeHTML( final CharSequence str )
2752    {
2753        final var retValue = nonNull( str ) ? HTML50.unescape( str ) : null;
2754
2755        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2756        return retValue;
2757    }   //  unescapeHTML()
2758
2759    /**
2760     *  Unescapes a string containing entity escapes to a string containing the
2761     *  actual Unicode characters corresponding to the escapes and writes it to
2762     *  the given
2763     *  {@link Appendable}.
2764     *  Supports HTML 4.0 entities.<br>
2765     *  <br>For example, the string
2766     *  &quot;&amp;lt;Fran&amp;ccedil;ais&amp;gt;&quot; will become
2767     *  &quot;&lt;Fran&ccedil;ais&gt;&quot;.<br>
2768     *  <br>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2769     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2770     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.
2771     *
2772     *  @param  appendable  The appendable receiving the unescaped string.
2773     *  @param  str The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2774     *  @throws NullArgumentException   The appendable is {@code null}.
2775     *  @throws IOException An IOException occurred.
2776     *
2777     *  @see #escapeHTML(CharSequence)
2778     *
2779     *  @since 0.0.5
2780     */
2781    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2782    public static final void unescapeHTML( final Appendable appendable, final CharSequence str ) throws IOException
2783    {
2784        requireNonNullArgument( appendable, "appendable" );
2785
2786        if( nonNull( str ) ) HTML50.unescape( appendable, str );
2787    }   //  unescapeHTML()
2788
2789    /**
2790     *  Parses Strings in the format &quot;<code>&#92;uXXXX</code>&quot;,
2791     *  containing the textual representation of a single Unicode character, to
2792     *  the respective Unicode character. Some Unicode characters will be
2793     *  represented as <i>surrogate pairs</i> in Java, so the String that is
2794     *  returned by this method may contain more than one {@code char}.<br>
2795     *  <br>The input format for this method is used in Java source code
2796     *  Strings, in Java {@code .properties} files, in C/C++ source code, in
2797     *  JavaScript source, &hellip;
2798     *
2799     *  @param  s   The input String with the Unicode escape sequence.
2800     *  @return The Unicode character.
2801     *  @throws ValidationException The input is {@code null}, empty, or cannot
2802     *      be parsed as a unicode escape sequence.
2803     *
2804     *  @since 0.0.5
2805     *  @deprecated Use
2806     *      {@link CharSetUtils#unescapeUnicode(CharSequence)}
2807     *      instead.
2808     */
2809    @Deprecated( since ="0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2810    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2811    public static final String unescapeUnicode( final CharSequence s )
2812    {
2813        return CharSetUtils.unescapeUnicode( s );
2814    }   //  unescapeUnicode()
2815
2816    /**
2817     *  <p>{@summary Unescapes an XML string containing XML entity escapes to a
2818     *  string containing the actual Unicode characters corresponding to the
2819     *  escapes.}</p>
2820     *  <p>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2821     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2822     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.</p>
2823     *
2824     *  @param  str The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2825     *  @return A new unescaped {@code String}, {@code null} if the given
2826     *      string was already {@code null}.
2827     *
2828     *  @see #escapeXML(CharSequence)
2829     *  @see #escapeXML(Appendable,CharSequence)
2830     *
2831     *  @since 0.0.5
2832     */
2833    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2834    public static final String unescapeXML( final CharSequence str )
2835    {
2836        final var retValue = nonNull( str ) ? XML.unescape( str ) : null;
2837
2838        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2839        return retValue;
2840    }   //  unescapeXML()
2841
2842    /**
2843     *  <p>{@summary Unescapes an XML String containing XML entity escapes to a
2844     *  String containing the actual Unicode characters corresponding to the
2845     *  escapes and writes it to the given
2846     *  {@link Appendable}.}</p>
2847     *  <p>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2848     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2849     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.</p>
2850     *
2851     *  @param  appendable  The appendable receiving the unescaped string.
2852     *  @param  str The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2853     *  @throws NullArgumentException   The writer is {@code null}.
2854     *  @throws IOException An IOException occurred.
2855     *
2856     *  @see #escapeXML(CharSequence)
2857     *
2858     *  @since 0.0.5
2859     */
2860    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2861    public static final void unescapeXML( final Appendable appendable, final CharSequence str ) throws IOException
2862    {
2863        requireNonNullArgument( appendable, "appendable" );
2864
2865        if( nonNull( str ) ) XML.unescape( appendable, str );
2866    }   //  unescapeXML()
2867
2868    /**
2869     *  Returns the Unicode escape sequence for the given character. This will
2870     *  return &quot;&#92;u0075&quot; for the letter 'u', and
2871     *  &quot;&#92;u003c&quot; for the smaller-than sign '&lt;'.
2872     *
2873     *  @param  c   The character.
2874     *  @return The escape sequence.
2875     *
2876     *  @deprecated Use
2877     *      {@link CharSetUtils#escapeCharacter(char)}
2878     *      instead.
2879     *
2880     *  @since 0.0.5
2881     */
2882    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2883    @Deprecated( forRemoval = true )
2884    public static final String unicodeEscape( final char c ) { return escapeCharacter( c ); }
2885
2886    /**
2887     *  Returns the Unicode escape sequence for the given code point. This will
2888     *  return &quot;&#92;u0075&quot; for the letter 'u', and
2889     *  &quot;&#92;u003c&quot; for the smaller-than sign '&lt;'.
2890     *
2891     *  @param  codePoint   The character.
2892     *  @return The escape sequence.
2893     *
2894     *  @deprecated Use
2895     *      {@link #escapeUnicode(int)}
2896     *      instead.
2897     *
2898     *  @since 0.0.5
2899     */
2900    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2901    @Deprecated( forRemoval = true )
2902    public static final String unicodeEscape( final int codePoint ) { return escapeUnicode( codePoint ); }
2903
2904    /**
2905     *  Returns the given URL encoded String in its decoded form, using the
2906     *  UTF-8 character encoding.<br>
2907     *  <br>Internally, this method and
2908     *  {@link #urlEncode(CharSequence)}
2909     *  make use of the methods from
2910     *  {@link java.net.URLDecoder}
2911     *  and
2912     *  {@link java.net.URLEncoder}, respectively. The methods here were
2913     *  introduced to simplify the handling, as first only the UTF-8 encoding
2914     *  should be used - making the second argument for the methods
2915     *  {@link java.net.URLDecoder#decode(String, String) decode()}/
2916     *  {@link java.net.URLEncoder#encode(String, String) encode()}
2917     *  obsolete - and second, they could throw an
2918     *  {@link UnsupportedEncodingException} - although this should never occur
2919     *  when UTF-8 encoding is used.
2920     *
2921     *  @param  s   The input String.
2922     *  @return The decoded result.
2923     *
2924     *  @see java.net.URLDecoder#decode(String, String)
2925     *
2926     *  @since 0.0.5
2927     */
2928    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2929    public static final String urlDecode( final CharSequence s )
2930    {
2931        final var retValue = decode( requireNonNullArgument( s, "s" ).toString(), UTF8 );
2932
2933        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2934        return retValue;
2935    }   //  urlDecode()
2936
2937    /**
2938     *  Returns the given String in its URL encoded form, using the
2939     *  UTF-8 character encoding.
2940     *
2941     *  @param  s   The input String.
2942     *  @return The URL encoded result.
2943     *
2944     *  @see java.net.URLEncoder#encode(String, String)
2945     *  @see #urlDecode(CharSequence)
2946     *
2947     *  @since 0.0.5
2948     */
2949    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2950    public static final String urlEncode( final CharSequence s )
2951    {
2952        final var retValue = encode( requireNonNullArgument( s, "s" ).toString(), UTF8 );
2953
2954        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2955        return retValue;
2956    }   //  urlEncode()
2957}
2958//  class StringUtils
